last_post.content:
Large Language Models are Versatile Decomposers for Table-based Reasoning

Microsoft just published a paper - modestly titled "AGIEval: A Human-Centric Benchmark for Evaluating Foundation Models" - that, no joke, uses readily available *online* sample SAT questions to evaluate the GPT class LLMs. The problem, of course, is that same data was likely used to train the same models. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2304.06364.pdf

Elsevier and other academic publishers have pivoted from oligopolistic publishers to researcher-surveillance vendors. They track everything you do and sell the analysis back to your employers.

It's about time that academics became more aware of this.

title: Seamful XAI: Operationalizing Seamful Design in Explainable AI

last_post.content:
Here's a new idea from the #HCXAI #CHI2023 workshop: Seams in AI systems are mismatches or gaps between the design & expectations of a system versus how that system is actually used. It's like how everyone expects AI to take over the world when real AI systems still confuse cats with dogs...

This idea is discussed further in this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.06753

I just read the best paper I've seen yet this year, Sam Zhang's work on confusion between inferential uncertainty and outcome variability.

In the context of a trial or experiment, inferential uncertainty refers to our statistical confidence that two groups are different. Outcome variability refers to how much variation there is in individual outcomes within a single group.

IMO confusion about this is ubiquitous in biomedical science.

Here's the paper: https://osf.io/preprints/socarxiv/5tcgs/

@lakens As a philosopher of science, I agree. One of the main lessons I learned from doing my PhD among scientists is that there are limitations on what can be extracted from case studies, and that a better methodology in many cases is to adopt a review (or even meta-analysis) approach. A bit of shameless self-promotion, I have tried to implement such an approach myself: https://doi.org/10.1007/s13164-020-00492-8

Having said that, I do think case studies can be made interesting by noting how particular cases have structural similarities to other cases. Even if a single case is not enough for a general conclusion, it serves as an illustration if one can show that it resembles other cases in some relevant manner. If one can show that, generalization is warranted and philosophical conclusions are justified.

New study: "Our findings show that tenure-track women are at parity with tenure-track men in three domains (grant funding, journal acceptances, and recommendation letters) and are advantaged over men in a fourth domain (hiring). For teaching ratings and salaries, we found evidence of bias against women."
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/epub/10.1177/15291006231163179

#academia #bias #gender #parity

BERT with pixel input of text performs much worse than BERT on text [1].

That being said, we can also convert non-textual visual info into words or narration for better performance. One relevant example is the use of narration in video models.

title: Option-Driven Design: Context, Tradeoffs, and Considerations for Accessibility

last_post.content:
👋🏻 Hello #a11y folks, but especially those who build software and games: I have a new piece out where I talk about "Option-Driven Design" and how it is not only a huge trend in accessibility, but surprisingly underdiscussed.

Considering when, why, and how we give users options for accessibility matters!

I hope that this micro-paper serves just to get the conversation started! There's so much to discuss.

PDF here (HTML incoming):

https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.08748

title: Don’t Just Tell Me, Ask Me: AI Systems that Intelligently Frame Explanations as Questions Improve Human Logical Discernment Accuracy over Causal AI explanations | Proceedings of the 2023 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems

last_post.content:
Interesting new #CHI2023 paper on human-AI interaction. Key point: in the context of AI-supported decision making, asking a question (“If one person played video games and was aggressive does it follow that everyone that plays violent video games will be aggressive?”) leads to higher quality decisions than suggesting an answer (“If one person played video games and was aggressive, it does not follow that everyone that plays violent video games will be aggressive”).

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3544548.3580672

title: Acute and postacute sequelae associated with SARS-CoV-2 reinfection - Nature Medicine

last_post.content:
I was reading today's Nature article, sighing with some of its inevitable tone, sensing a thread coming on, and then looked at the graph provided

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-02051-3

It looks like its "not much" additional risk. Right?

Its a trap! The risk ratios shown are show log plot, not linear.

Fortunately, @tjradcliffe beat me to it. He replotted the risk ratios into linear.

After the 3rd infection, the hospitalization risk is 40% or 400 per 1000.

Read that again.

#SARS2 #sarscov2 #COVID19

I have a new article out in #VisualCommunication today, which uses unsupervised machine learning to discover genres in the AI2D-RST diagram corpus (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10579-020-09517-1).

I also propose a new method for quantifying information about layout, which turned out to be crucial for identifying diagram genres.

You can read the article here (open access): https://doi.org/10.1177/14703572231161829

title: ACROCPoLis: A Descriptive Framework for Making Sense of Fairness

last_post.content:
How to model sociotechnical aspects of computer and AI applications in ways conducive to assessing their fairness?

In this forthcoming FAccT paper, a collaboration with @vdignum and the Umeå Responsible AI group, we present a tool to help doing that: the ACROCPoLis framewok.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11217

The framework provides a sort of ontology to identify relevant components to consider when assessing the fairness of computer and AI applications. 1/4
#AIfairness #FAccTConference #aiethics

Also, the second @princeton affiliated paper of the day: our collaborator Kelly Mack is presenting her research on Inclusive Avatars as part of her internship with our team last summer.

Check out her presentation at #CHI2023 in Room X11+X12, Tue, Apr 25 | 14:30 - 14:44 :chi:

Previous thread on the research: https://hci.social/@andresmh/110216944014635085

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01880

The paper "Shall We Really Do It Again?" by Schmidt from 2009 is still on of the best papers discussing replication studies in the social sciences, with a good overview of different types and functions. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0015108 I highly recommend reading it - the well-meant advice not to conduct replication studies when you are dependent upon publications, and the hope this will change in the next decades, is an especially nice reminder of how far we have come!

title: ChatABL: Abductive Learning via Natural Language Interaction with ChatGPT

last_post.content:
📝 ChatABL: Abductive Learning via Natural Language Interaction with ChatGPT 📚👾

"ChatABL utilizes the reasoning ability of large language models to correct incomplete logic facts, optimize the deciphering performance of perceptual module, and improve the interpretability of perceptual module." [gal30b+] 🤖 #CL #AI

🔗 https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.11107v1 #arxiv

title: Understanding Human Intervention in the Platform Economy: A case study of an indie food delivery service

last_post.content:
Did you know there are hundreds of indie food delivery platforms?

But why do people choose indies over DoorDash or Uber Eats?

Because it gives people more 🌟 agency 🌟 and because its infrastructure embraces 🔨 humans doing repair work.

Our collaborator @samanthadalal led this study of dozens of couriers, restaurateurs, customers and platform staff of an indie platform in Colorado.

She's presenting in Hall E, Tue, Apr 25 | 09:28 - 09:42 #CHI2023 :chi:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03523

Watching Sam Robertson present her paper written with Apple colleagues on developing an infovis tool to help translation practitioners find and mitigate errors at #chi2023, read the paper here https://arxiv.org/pdf/2304.05967.pdf

10 years after we created Registered Reports, the thing critics assured us would never (in a million years) happen has happened: @Nature is offering them.

The Registered Reports initiative just went up a gear and we are one step closer to eradicating publication bias and reporting bias from science.

Congratulations to all involved in achieving this milestone.

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00506-2

My new article on “Questionable Metascience Practices."

Open access: https://doi.org/10.36850/mr4
